sentences: Naomi Littlebear Morena (born 1950) is a musician and writer most known for her work "You Can't Kill the Spirit," a feminist resistance anthem which was sung by over 30,000 women at the Greenham Common Women's Peace Camp in the 1980s.

Morena was described as a self-taught artist who "emerged on her own brilliance" and a "hippie street person hitchhiking" between Los Angeles and Portland, Oregon by Knapp, a fellow member of the Izquierda Ensemble, which toured nationally in the 1970s.
Morena also created "one of the first plays to feature a Chicana lesbian as a main character," first performed in 1980 and titled Survivor: A Lesbian Rock Opera.
Morena's work has been noted to be "currently out of print and rarely produced."

Morena commented on Mudcat Caf√© in 2012 that she wrote "You Can't Kill the Spirit" when she was in the Izquierda Ensemble in the 1970s and is "humbled by the stories I have heard regarding the singing of my song at the various protests, peace and healing gatherings through out the world."
